Thank you to the Nutrition Assistance Program for the tour and insightful discussions on the challenges and opportunities within your services.

Your team’s dedication to supporting the well-being of families across the CNMI is truly commendable. I look forward to continuing our collaboration to strengthen food security and community health.

Honored to visit Mount Carmel School and speak with the bright young minds about my role as a US Delegate.

We had an engaging conversation about personal goals, leadership, and global citizenship. I was truly inspired by the students’ thoughtful questions and their vision for the future. Grateful for the opportunity to connect, share, and learn together.

A press conference with Governor Apatang and Lt. Governor Mendiola to address the CNMI’s critically low financial state. We spoke openly about the urgent challenges ahead and the tough decisions that must be made to sustain essential services and protect our community. Collaboration and transparency will be key as we move forward together.

Homelessness amongst veterans is on the rise in America.

That's why I introduced the Heroes Owning and Materializing Equity (HOME) Act of 2025 — to promote stability for veterans through enhanced financial literacy and support. 

No veteran should have to lose their home or face financial instability because they lack access to the right tools or resources. We can—and must—equip our heroes with the knowledge needed to thrive.

Thank you to @RepVanOrden, @RepMoylan, and @RepAmata for cosponsoring this bill. It's crucial we break down barriers preventing veterans from acquiring financial counseling & owning and maintaining homes.

Yesterday, I advocated for a stronger Coast Guard presence in the CNMI. They bring value to the Marianas, America's westernmost border, and are essential to protecting our national security. https://t.co/iaijfnyjnR

Today, we pause to honor the brave men and women who made the ultimate sacrifice for our freedom. Their courage and dedication ensure that we continue to live in a nation of liberty and opportunity.

On Wednesday, I had a great conversation with House Armed Services Committee Chairman @RepMikeRogersAL about ongoing Department of Defense investments in the CNMI.

As his committee works on the 2026 National Defense Authorization Act - the primary vehicle for funding these projects - it was a valuable moment to discuss where we are, what’s needed, and how federal policy can better support CNMI-owned businesses in military contracting. We also talked about labor access in the Marianas and why economic stability in our islands is critical to national security.

Thank you, Chairman Rogers, for taking the time.
https://t.co/pWiVkPTwcR

On Tuesday, I met with @lisamurkowski of Alaska to reintroduce myself and discuss key issues affecting the CNMI. I emphasized the urgent need for federal assistance as our economy continues to struggle, with our tourism industry facing a steep decline.

I also took the opportunity to thank Senator Murkowski for her continued friendship and steadfast support for the Marianas and all U.S. territories. As a well-deserved token of appreciation, I presented her with a mwar from the islands.

When I speak to veterans back home, they share with me the immense challenges they face when trying to access medical care. Far too often, they are forced to travel thousands of miles for basic care while the federal government fails to provide sufficient support.

This week, I introduced the TRAVEL Act, which aims to change that.

Once passed, the TRAVEL Act will empower the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to appoint traveling physicians to aid underserved communities like the Marianas and improve healthcare access for our veterans.

Thank you to @HouseVetAffairs Chair @RepBost for supporting this bill and @RepMoylan and @RepAmata for cosponsoring. This is the first step in a long journey to get our heroes the care they so rightfully deserve.

To learn more about the TRAVEL Act, read my press release here: https://t.co/IPqwmY12ws

It's official: After a long time pushing, the CNMI is finally getting a VA admin staffer on June 16.

It takes strength and courage to start and run a small business. Let's take this time to appreciate them and work to get them the resources and support they need to thrive.

Today, I want to take time to celebrate Jemenei Day, which marks the 46th anniversary of the independence and the adoption of the Constitution of the Republic of the Marshall Islands. 

The Northern Mariana Islands and the Marshall Islands share a unique and deeply connected history. Both were once part of the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands (TTPI), a United Nations–mandated territory administered by the United States after World War II. 

Though we took different paths following the end of the TTPI, our shared history continues to shape the enduring bonds between our peoples and cultures. 

Jeramon and best wishes to the Marshallese community of the CNMI and all the people of the Marshall Islands!

Proud to support American innovation and financial freedom. Grateful for the partnership. 🫡

I urge my colleagues to join us in backing legislation like the BITCOIN Act of 2025 to strengthen U.S. resilience.

In solidarity with the people of the Marianas and the global community, both within and beyond the Catholic Church, I am saddened by the passing of His Holiness Pope Francis.

I’ve valued Pope Francis’ leadership over the past decade. He has been a beacon of hope. His calls for acceptance of our neighbors and his advocacy for the less fortunate have left a profound impression on me.

I am praying for the Vatican, the College of the Cardinals, and Catholics everywhere, that the coming conclave brings forth a servant leader who will continue Pope Francis’ legacy of love, humility, and grace.

@RepEdCase of Hawaii has long been a dedicated advocate for Pacific Islands issues. I had the privilege of meeting with him on Tuesday to seek his invaluable mentorship and to discuss matters that affect the Pacific community. As a member of the influential Appropriations Committee and its Subcommittees on Defense and Homeland Security, Rep. Case plays a crucial role in shaping policy that impacts our region. 

Representing a former noncontiguous territory with an economy heavily reliant on tourism and the military, we share so many common interests and we have a tremendous opportunity to collaborate to see our region prosper. Thank you Congressman Case!

This week, the Subcommittee on Economic Opportunity convened to vote on legislation that will directly impact our veterans. If signed into law, these bills will increase  accessibility to mental healthcare, educational and vocational counseling, and more. One example is H.R. 1793, or the Veterans Readiness and Employment Transparency Act of 2025. I’m a proud cosponsor and fully support its mission to reduce wait times for disabled veterans seeking career assistance, establish a dedicated hotline for VR&E, and require regional offices to post information about transitional programs. 

When veterans transition from the military to the civilian world, resources must be readily available to ensure they have everything they need to succeed academically and professionally. Our veterans serve us, and I will always vote in favor of safeguarding their future.

I presented @SpeakerJohnson with a traditional Chamorro necklace, or "Sinahi," carved of giant clam shell by Master Carver and Tinian resident Mathew C. Masga, at a recent meeting. 

Thank you, Speaker Johnson, for your leadership in the House and for continuing to fight for everyday Americans.
Thank you!!
Thank you for the birthday wishes @RepDavidRouzer and @TransportGOP! https://t.co/KvKSYHPHGk

Had the pleasure of seeing my friend @SecretaryBurgum at last night's 2025 Cherry Blossom Festival hosted by the Ambassador of Japan. 

The CNMI works closely with the Department of Interior to advance a wide range of initiatives relating to our community. 

His partnership with the CNMI is deeply valued, and I appreciate his willingness to listen to our concerns and challenges.

Geographically isolated regions struggle when it comes to airport infrastructure. Not only are they used for travel, but they are also critical lifelines. As the Defense Department makes investments in the CNMI, federal, state, and local governments must all ensure our airports are in order, as our military is dependent on them.

The witnesses at today's hearing have got it right. We need a thriving tourism industry with multiple source markets in order to be self-sustainable—federal subsidies will only be a band-aid on the problem. Instead of a handout, we need a hand up.

This weekend, I was visited by some special guests. I welcomed U.S. Army PV2 Raymond Anthony S. Mercado, his wife Shaylene Flores Mercado, and their super cute son Tepoeaofeani Moki F. Mercado in Washington, DC. Raymond just completed his Advanced Individual Training (AIT) and is a 91B wheeled vehicle mechanic. Now that he has completed his AIT, he will soon be leaving for his next assignment in Germany. 

Our servicemen and women make the ultimate sacrifice in defending our freedoms. Not only do they make a sacrifice, but so do their families who support them every step of the way. It was an honor to spend time with the Mercado family, and to witness the strength and dedication of both the soldier and their loved ones.

A big thank you to the CNMI veterans who joined me for lunch a few weeks ago to share their experiences and discuss the ongoing challenges in accessing healthcare and benefits in the Commonwealth. Your time, honesty, and insight are invaluable as we continue the fight in Congress to ensure you receive the care and support you’ve earned. 

We talked about the vacancy at the CNMI VA Office, issues with the BeneTravel program, and the burden of traveling to Guam for basic services like physical therapy. Veterans also raised concerns about registration barriers, data accuracy, and how we can get accurate data on our veteran population. 

I’m committed to continuing our collaboration—supporting veteran registration drives, sharing updates on Guam CBOC outreach to the CNMI, and working on policy and legislative solutions that lead to real, lasting improvements in the services you receive. Thank you for your service—and for helping guide this work.

In communities like the Northern Marianas, veterans already lack access to care. If programs like the Transitional Assistance Program (TAP) are at a 52% success rate nationally, communities like ours are surely well below that. Amidst an already struggling economy, we must ensure that our servicemen and women have jobs when they return home.

The Transition Assistance Program (TAP) is supposed to support veterans' transition into civilian life and help them join the workforce.

The US VA and Labor Departments manage this program and make it mandatory for veterans. They want to keep this program going, but one thing stands out to me: it has a 52% success rate. That is outright unacceptable.

Why is this tolerable to the VA? The department must work toward better outcomes. There are so many questions surrounding this issue. America and our veterans need answers. And more importantly, our veterans deserve better.

Today, we celebrate Covenant Day, a moment to reflect on the vision, foresight, and persistence of our founders, the meaning of choosing to be Americans, and the progress we’ve made since joining the American political family.

But the Covenant is more than just a historic document—it’s a living commitment.

To me, it’s both an ideal and a tool, one that survives through our actions and advocacy. It reminds us that our unique identity within the United States must be continually protected and uplifted.

As we mark 49 years since the signing, it’s up to us to give life to this agreement, to defend our rights, and to stay true to the principles of self-government and self-determination—even when it’s hard.

Here’s to honoring the past, meeting the moment, and continuing to define our future.

Happy Covenant Day, CNMI!

#cnmi

Happy International Women’s Day!

This is a time to show appreciation to the strong women in our lives, to reflect on how far women’s rights have come, and most importantly to empower the women around us.

When I was younger, I watched as my Mom served in the NMI legislature, and I want to thank her for inspiring me to get involved in public service. When we step up to create change, we don’t just inspire women of today—we empower generations to come.

#WomensHistoryMonth

I am a proud co-sponsor of H.R.1329. I urge my colleagues to support its passage.
Just to set the record straight, not once was the CNMI controlled or influenced by the Soviets.

The tourists aren't coming. Legacy businesses are leaving. The CNMI is on the cusp of economic collapse, and I am drafting a bill asking the federal government for a $400 million bailout as requested by my Governor.

Furthermore, we are being strangled by one-size-fits-all policies crafted by those who have no understanding of life on the ground in our community. For far too long, there have been conversations ABOUT the CNMI but not WITH the CNMI. These conversations often miss the point—our biggest threat is not the tourists. Although birth tourism is a problem, we are combating it like never before, and the CNMI has urged Congress to amend birthright citizenship in the Covenant. Our real threat right now happens to be economic collapse which would make us vulnerable to foreign adversaries and, in turn, put the nation at risk.

We have ONE industry in the Commonwealth and voices in DC are trying to take that away without supplying a viable alternative. I am urging @secrubio to work with embassies in Japan, Australia, the Philippines etc., to help us expand our tourism market. Additionally, we need fewer regulations on the CNMI, expanded labor access, and more economic relief.
7 bills. All passed unanimously. Yes, bipartisanship in Congress DOES happen—and it works.

I am very sad to hear about the passing of Congressman Turner. His sacrifice and devotion as a public servant to his community is admirable. We lost a remarkable leader today.

His family is in my thoughts and prayers during this trying time as they grieve.

It was great speaking with my friend, @RepYoungKim about the importance of the Northern Marianas to American national security, yesterday. Rep. Kim, as someone who once lived in the neighboring Guam, understands the hardship we endure in leveling-up our economy.

As the most western border of the United States, the Northern Marianas plays a crucial role in our national security.

When we promote economic stability in the Marianas, we secure our nation.

Congresswoman King-Hinds questions witnesses at this week's joint House and Senate VSO hearing on policies geared toward rural and isolated communities. https://t.co/ZLEFoDFx4v

It's important to discuss which type of care is best for our veterans -- yet for many rural and isolated communities, this is a challenge we wish we faced. Our challenge isn't choosing which care is the best route, it's about getting access to care in the first place.

Before we have the conversation about WHICH type of care is best for our veterans, we should first ensure they all HAVE access to care to begin with.

My first vote in Congress just wrapped up this morning.

The CNMI needs to build a sustainable economy that does not rely on federal handouts. 

If OIA and IGIA are serious about fulfilling their mandates, then it is time to stop simply monitoring economic distress and start eliminating the policies that create it.

The CNMI is tired of waiting. Tired of having the same discussions, raising the same concerns, and receiving the same responses year after year.

We need bold steps. And we need them now. 

We need to reassess IGIA’s effectiveness and ensure it is more than a discussion forum—it must drive real policy change.

Thank you @SecretaryBurgum for sitting down with delegates and governors of U.S. territories to hear our concerns at yesterday's IGIA Summit at @Interior. 

We are just as American as anyone else. Policies promoting our development are desperately needed.

I appreciate your empathy and compassion toward me and my colleagues. Your openness and commitment to action is refreshing. I look forward to working with you in leveling up our communities.

People keep asking me "Kim, what do you call 'snow' on the islands."

Girl, there is no word in Chamorro for that. We don't get snow in the Marianas! And if it do be snowing, it's the end of the world! #snow #frosnauchan https://t.co/7wCwi3od6g

My colleagues in the @HouseVetAffairs today were debating whether or not we should have direct or community care for our veterans. Choosing between where to receive care...I wish we had that problem.

The CNMI doesn't even have options. We have ONE doctor in Saipan that sees patients two times a week. The nearest VA hospital is in Hawai'i, which is nearly 4,000 miles away. Often, many of our veterans that are on a fixed income have to pay out of pocket to travel to get healthcare and then wait months to be reimbursed.

Let's ensure that ALL veterans, regardless of their zip code, get the healthcare they deserve. Being from a territory doesn't make us any less American.

Congresswoman King-Hinds questions Justin Hooper, CEO and Chairman of the First Financial Bank in the Cross Timbers Region, on how the federal government can give small businesses and communities more access to capital. https://t.co/7ae8yRW6HU

I sat down with Rep. Tom Tiffany (WI-07) last week to discuss the many similarities and unique challenges faced by rural mainland areas and places like the CNMI.

We also had a productive conversation in regard to combatting Chinese Birth Tourism and the importance of the CNMI to America's national security.

Thank you @RepTiffany for expressing your desire to help tackle issues pertaining to the CNMI. I look forward to collaborating with you and providing up-to-date information related to my district's issues so we can respond in an effective manner.

All businesses in the Northern Marianas are small businesses. 

They spend 1/4 of their revenue on burdensome regulatory compliance.

And nearly 90% of SBA loan applications from the CNMI are denied. The lowest in the nation.

One-size-fits-all federal regulations do not help rural and isolated communities.
